title: Mirelo raises $41M from Index and a16z to put sound at the center of AI video

paragraphs.content: Berlin-based AI startup **Mirelo** has raised **$41 million in seed funding** to tackle what investors are calling AI video’s “silent problem” by automatically generating synchronized audio for visual content.The round was co-led by **Index Ventures** and **Andreessen Horowitz (a16z)**, with participation from existing backers including Atlantic.vc and TriplePoint Capital.Mirelo’s technology analyzes video motion and context to produce matching sound effects and music in seconds, aiming to replace today’s slow, manual process of searching stock libraries or commissioning custom sound.The new capital will be used to expand its AI research, product development, and creator-facing tools as demand for AI video and gaming content accelerates.

paragraphs.content: Index Ventures describes Mirelo as a **“foundation model company”** for sound that brings “emotion and impact to visual media,” highlighting the founders’ roots as musicians and AI researchers from major tech labs and European institutions.TechFundingNews notes that the $41M round, worth about **€35 million**, is among the largest seed financings in the AI audio space and signals that sound is emerging as the “next frontier of generative media.”Mirelo’s models are already accessible via APIs and a browser-based studio, targeting everyone from social video creators to game developers who need fast, high-quality audio drafts.By positioning itself as the “audio layer for all visual content,” the company is pitching its tools as an augmentation of, not a replacement for, professional sound designers.

sections.title: Inside Mirelo’s plan to solve AI video’s “silent problem”

paragraphs.content: Mirelo’s core proposition is that while AI systems can now generate realistic video, much of that content still ships **without sound or with generic, poorly synced audio**, undermining immersion for viewers.To address this gap, the startup’s models interpret on-screen movement, pacing, and scene context to generate synchronized sound effects and musical beds that track what is happening in each frame.Company materials describe use cases ranging from TikTok-style clips to full game levels, where creators can iterate on “tension” or “tone” in a few seconds instead of hours in a digital audio workstation.The goal is to let non-experts reach near-professional sound quickly while giving audio specialists a faster way to prototype and explore alternatives.

paragraphs.content: Mirelo is currently distributing its technology through **APIs and a web-based studio**, enabling developers and creators to plug AI-generated audio directly into their video workflows.Its studio product follows a freemium model with a paid tier pitched at individual creators, while API usage targets platforms and larger teams that need scalable sound for volumes of content.The company presents this as a structural change in how sound is produced: instead of treating audio as a late-stage add-on, producers can “audition” different soundscapes early in the creative process and keep them consistent through post-production.By collapsing discovery, composition, and synchronization into a single AI step, Mirelo aims to remove what investors describe as a major “creative bottleneck” in modern video and game production.

sections.title: Musicians-turned-researchers and the race for AI audio’s next frontier

paragraphs.content: Index Ventures characterizes Mirelo’s founding team as **“musicians-turned-AI researchers”** who previously worked in big tech AI labs and top European research institutions, arguing this mix of art and science is crucial for credible audio tools.In its investment note, Index says Mirelo’s “state-of-the-art AI audio models break new frontiers in AI” and specifically praised their ability to add emotional depth to videos and games.Coverage from TechFundingNews and other outlets frames the $41M seed round as a strong signal that investors see audio as the next competitive arena after language and image models.With this capital, Mirelo plans to scale its engineering, research, and product teams in Berlin to support both everyday creators and professional studios.

paragraphs.content: Looking ahead, Mirelo is positioning itself as an **“audio layer for all visual content,”** betting that the explosion of AI-generated and user-generated video will require far more sound than current workflows can supply.The company’s roadmap includes building larger foundation models to keep audio style and quality consistent across entire projects, from rough cuts to final exports.Industry observers say this could reshape how sound designers work—shifting their focus from repetitive syncing tasks to higher-level creative decisions—while giving small teams access to capabilities previously reserved for big-budget productions.As generative video tools become more mainstream, Mirelo’s backers argue that whoever solves synchronized, emotionally resonant audio at scale will own a critical layer of the media stack.
